resources.name: WaniKani
resources.description: Kanji learning through mnemonics and SRS.
resources.descriptionLong: WaniKani teaches over 2,000 kanji through a structured curriculum using mnemonics and spaced repetition. Each kanji comes with memorable stories, and readings are learned through vocabulary. The radical-based approach builds understanding systematically.
resources.notes: First 3 levels free. Most popular kanji learning platform.

resources.name: Remembering the Kanji
resources.descriptionLong: Remembering the Kanji by James Heisig teaches kanji meanings through imaginative stories and mnemonics. The method focuses on learning meanings first, with readings learned later through vocabulary. A proven approach for many learners.
resources.notes: Volume 1 covers meanings. Volume 2 covers readings.

resources.name: Kodansha Kanji Learner's Course
resources.nameJa: 講談社漢字学習コース
resources.descriptionLong: The Kodansha Kanji Learner's Course presents 2,300 kanji in a carefully designed order that builds on previously learned characters. Each entry includes meanings, readings, vocabulary, and mnemonics. A comprehensive and well-organized approach.
resources.notes: Excellent systematic approach. Anki decks available.

resources.name: Kanji Study
resources.description: Comprehensive kanji app with writing practice.
resources.descriptionLong: Kanji Study is a dedicated kanji learning app covering all joyo kanji plus more. It includes detailed information, writing practice with stroke order, flashcards, and quizzes. Organized by JLPT level, grade, and frequency.
resources.priceDetails: Free with in-app purchases for full content
resources.notes: Android only. One of the best kanji apps.

resources.name: Kanji Garden
resources.descriptionLong: Kanji Garden uses spaced repetition and mnemonics to teach kanji. The platform provides a structured learning path and tracks your progress. A good alternative to WaniKani with a different approach.
resources.priceDetails: Free tier available. Premium for full access.
resources.notes: Good free alternative for kanji learning.

resources.name: Jisho Kanji Search
resources.description: Kanji lookup with stroke order and details.
resources.descriptionLong: Jisho provides detailed kanji information including meanings, readings, stroke order, and example words. You can search by radical, stroke count, or draw the kanji. Essential reference tool.
resources.notes: Essential kanji reference. Supports drawing to search.

resources.name: Kanji Damage
resources.descriptionLong: Kanji Damage teaches kanji through memorable (often irreverent) mnemonics. The free resource covers 1,700+ kanji with a unique, humorous approach that helps many learners remember characters.

resources.name: Skritter
resources.descriptionLong: Skritter combines spaced repetition with handwriting practice for kanji. Write characters on your device and get instant feedback. The app tracks your progress and schedules reviews optimally.

resources.name: Kanji Koohii
resources.description: Community for RTK learners with SRS.
resources.descriptionLong: Kanji Koohii is a community site for learners using Remembering the Kanji. It includes an SRS system, shared mnemonics, and discussion forums. Great companion to the RTK book.

resources.name: Kanji Alive
resources.descriptionLong: Kanji Alive provides free kanji reference with stroke order animations, meanings, readings, and example words. The clean interface makes it easy to look up and study kanji.
